required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Distal Transradial Access for Percutaneous Coronary Intervention
clinical_study.official_title: PRESERVE Radial: A PRospEctive Randomized Clinical Study Comparing Radial ArtERy Intimal Hyperplasia Following Distal Vs. ForEarm TransRadial Arterial Access for Percutaneous Coronary Intervention

brief_summary.textblock: Prospective randomized non-blinded study to determine degree of vessel trauma and adverse remodeling of the proximal forearm radial artery following distal radial artery access (dTRA) for cardiac catheterization compared to standard forearm transradial access (fTRA).

detailed_description.textblock: To determine degree of vessel trauma and adverse remodeling of the proximal forearm radial artery, using ultrahigh resolution (55 MHz) ultrasound, following distal radial artery access (dTRA) for cardiac catheterization compared to standard forearm transradial access (fTRA) at 90 days post-procedure. Secondary outcome measures will include metrics of procedural success at 24 hours, as well as functional assessment of pain and motor strength of the ipsilateral upper extremity at 90 days post-procedure.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Prospective randomized non-blinded study evaluating whether distal radial artery access (dTRA) from the anatomic snuffbox is associated with less trauma and adverse remodeling to the forearm radial artery compared to standardard forearm radial access (fTRA).

primary_outcome.measure: Radial artery intimal medial thickness following dTRA and fTRA
primary_outcome.description: Intimal medial thickness (mm) of the forearm radial artery followed dTRA and fTRA as assessed using ultrahigh resolution 55 MHz ultrasound probe at 90 days post cardiac catheterization.

secondary_outcome.measure: Radial artery trauma followed dTRA and fTRA
secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants with limited access site intimal tears, dissections, thrombosis, occlusions and pseudoaneurysms of the radial artery as assessed using ultrahigh resolution 55 MHz ultrasound at the site of puncture at 24 hours and 90 days post cardiac catheterization

secondary_outcome.measure: Functional assessment of the ipsilateral upper extremity following dTRA and fTRA
secondary_outcome.description: Pain and motor strength of the ipsilateral upper extremity using the Borg (0-none to 10-maximal) and Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulders and Hand (DASH) (0-no disability to 100-most severe disability) scales 90 days post-cardiac catheterization.
Number of cannulation attempts prior to achieving successful vascular access
Time (minutes) from initial attempt to successful access of the radial artery.
Number of patients with failure of radial artery cannulation requiring crossover to alternative radial artery access or transfemoral access
Total procedural time (minutes) from time of access to completion of the cardiac catheterization.
Total duration of hemostasis (minutes) following completion of cardiac catheterization
Number of patients with EASY Class III or greater hematomas
Achievement of Thrombolysis in Myocardial Infarction (TIMI) 3 flow following percutaneous coronary intervention
Iatrogenic coronary dissection at the of cardiac catheterization
Periprocedural myocardial infarction requiring urgent revascularization within 24 hours post-cardiac catheterization.

arm_group.description: Subjects randomized to the experimental arm will undergo cardiac catheterization using distal transradial access (dTRA) to facilitate coronary angiography and percutaneous coronary intervention.

Cardiac catheterization to facilitate coronary angiography and percutaneous coronary intervention using the standard forearm radial artery which is the current standard of care in interventional cardiology.

intervention.description: Subjects randomized to the experimental arm will undergo coronary angiography and percutaneous coronary intervention using distal transradial access (dTRA)
Coronary angiography and percutaneous coronary intervention using the forearm radial artery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Consecutive patients undergoing elective and non-emergent TR LHC and/or PCI at the INOVA Heart and Vascular Institute
2. Able to provide informed consent.
3. Patients willing to complete a 90day post PCI radial artery ultrasound.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients with previous cannulation of both the right and left forearm RA's for coronary angiography and/or PCI. In patients with prior cannulation of one RA, the contralateral arm may be used for this study.
2. Patients who are not willing to undergo the necessary follow-up ultrasound examinations.
3. ST elevation myocardial infarction or other emergent PCI
4. Inability to provide informed consent

responsible_party.investigator_title: Director of Interventional Cardiology, Inova Heart and Vascular Institute

patient_data.ipd_description: Individual patient data including demographics, cardiac history indications for cardiac catheterization and all follow up data related to primary outcome, secondary ultrasound endpoints, interventional endpoints and secondary functional outcomes will be shared.
